snippet.title: Kenneth Cole outsleazes himself on Twitter with Syria 'joke'
snippet.description: The same man who made jokes about the Egyptian uprising being about his shoes, now offers a Syrian tweet that is as cynical as it is tasteless.

snippet.title: In Syria, a detained Internet activist remains in limbo
snippet.description: Two years ago this week, authorities arrested a computer programmer, Bassel Khartabil, involved in protests against the Syrian government. There's still no word on when he'll be released.

snippet.title: Litmus-like sensor could detect chemical weapons
snippet.description: The paper strips are designed to change from blue to pink within 30 seconds of exposure to even trace amounts of nerve gas.

snippet.title: Apple: Don't make nuclear weapons using iTunes
snippet.description: A mind-boggling clause is noticed by an eagle-eyed blogger in the iTunes agreement. Was Apple thinking of nuclear weapons that play Bieber as they explode?

snippet.title: Petman robot rocks gas mask, chemical suit
snippet.description: You wouldn't want to meet this camouflaged humanoid in a dark alley. For the time being, it's tethered to a treadmill.

snippet.title: Syria's chemical war (pictures)
snippet.description: With international norms on the use of chemical weapons allegedly violated, but weak political support for military action, what do we do?

snippet.title: Turkey tries to block YouTube after Syria security leak
snippet.description: The move comes just a week after authorities took similar action against Twitter, as the country's prime minister faces growing criticism for limiting free speech.

snippet.title: Defending against chemical, biological weapons
snippet.description: At the U.S. Army's Dugway Proving Grounds facility in the Utah desert, researchers look for ways to protect soldiers against "bugs" that could easily kill or sideline them.

snippet.title: Photos: How the Army tests biological and chemical weapons
snippet.description: At the U.S. Army's Dugway Proving Grounds facility in the Utah desert, scientists look for ways to protect soldiers against various chemical and biological weapons they might encounter in combat.

snippet.title: See the light on laser weapons, think tank urges
snippet.description: True, the Pentagon hasn't yet gotten the hoped-for payoff from its R&D on directed-energy weapons. But there's always tomorrow.
